quotes.topic_title: Introduction and Background
quotes.text: If you were literally founding a new company from scratch with the same mission, how would you execute on that mission using a fully AI native approach? If you can't, then you should find a buyer and then if you really care about this mission, go and start the next carnation of it.
quotes.speaker: Howie Liu
quotes.context: A hard reset test for whether your company’s strategy is truly AI-native—and a blunt call to consider radical options if it isn’t.

quotes.topic_title: Introduction and Background
quotes.text: If you want to cancel all your meetings for like a day or for an entire week and just go play around with every AI product you think could be relevant to Airtable, go do it.
quotes.speaker: Howie Liu
quotes.context: Practical advice to create focused time for hands-on AI tool exploration instead of trying to learn amid normal meeting load.

quotes.topic_title: Introduction and Background
quotes.text: It really does become more about individual attitude. There's a strong advantage to any of those three roles who can kind of cross over into the other two. As a PM, you need to start looking more like a hybrid PM prototyper, who has some good design sensibilities?
quotes.speaker: Howie Liu
quotes.context: A role-evolution model: AI rewards cross-functional “hybrid” builders and shifts leverage toward attitude and adaptability.

quotes.topic_title: Introduction and Background
quotes.text: Also, how he restructured his company into two groups, a fast thinking group, and a slow thinking group, which allowed their AI investments to significantly accelerate.
quotes.speaker: Lenny Rachitsky
quotes.context: A concrete org-design framework for AI execution: split teams by speed/iteration mode to accelerate AI investments.

quotes.topic_title: Viral “Airtable is dead” tweet fallout
quotes.text: Yeah, so basically none of it was true.
quotes.speaker: Howie Liu
quotes.context: A crisp reminder to verify viral claims—high-confidence narratives can be completely detached from reality.

quotes.topic_title: Viral “Airtable is dead” tweet fallout
quotes.text: And they just literally had incorrect numbers by a strong multiple on what our revenue scale was, what our growth rate was.
quotes.speaker: Howie Liu
quotes.context: Highlights how misinformation can be quantitatively wrong (not just slightly off), underscoring the need for rigorous data validation.

quotes.topic_title: Viral “Airtable is dead” tweet fallout
quotes.text: I think that the more surprising thing was just like this person has been tweeting a bunch of spicy takes that are not substantiated by real data or correct data, and yet this particular tweet went super viral and that was the perplexing part to me.
quotes.speaker: Howie Liu
quotes.context: Points to a distribution dynamic: virality often rewards “spicy takes” over substantiated accuracy, shaping reputational risk.

quotes.topic_title: Viral “Airtable is dead” tweet fallout
quotes.text: They did also issue a correction though. All In, did a follow-up episode, a few, I think weeks later saying, "Hey, we got the numbers wrong. We are revising our case and a view on Airtable."
quotes.speaker: Howie Liu
quotes.context: A concrete example of how corrections lag initial narratives—useful for planning comms response timing and expectations.

quotes.topic_title: Viral “Airtable is dead” tweet fallout
quotes.text: Yeah, it's tough. Twitter is such ... The incentives are so misaligned. It's just I tweet something people want to share, not truth.
quotes.speaker: Lenny Rachitsky
quotes.context: A practical mental model for interpreting social platforms: optimize for shareability, not accuracy, when assessing what you see (and how you respond).

quotes.topic_title: Why CEOs must become ICs again
quotes.text: Regardless, I think that now, we're entering this moment where ... Certainly every software product in my opinion, has to be refounded because AI is such a paradigm shift, it's not even just like the shift from desktop to mobile or on-prem to cloud where that was more like a very one time and somewhat predictable change in form factor.
quotes.speaker: Howie Liu
quotes.context: A contrarian framing that AI forces repeated “refounding,” not a one-time platform transition, implying continuous reinvention.

quotes.topic_title: Why CEOs must become ICs again
quotes.text: I think AI is so rapidly evolving that with every evolution, every new model release and every new type of capability that's released, it actually implies novel form factors and novel UX patterns to be invented to fully capitalize on those capabilities.
quotes.speaker: Howie Liu
quotes.context: A practical product-development lens: treat each model/capability jump as a trigger to invent new UX/form factors rather than bolt AI onto old ones.

quotes.topic_title: Why CEOs must become ICs again
quotes.text: And so to be continuously relevant and to refine product market fit in this era, I think you have to be of the details. There is no looking at it from 10,000 foot view and saying, "Oh, we're just going to throw a bunch of people at this problem."
quotes.speaker: Howie Liu
quotes.context: Actionable leadership guidance: PMF in AI requires hands-on detail work, not delegation-by-headcount from a high-level vantage point.

quotes.topic_title: Why CEOs must become ICs again
quotes.text: I would also say it's actually now also hard to taste the soup without participating in at least some part of creating the soup.
quotes.speaker: Howie Liu
quotes.context: A memorable mental model for “chief taste maker” leadership: you can’t judge AI product quality without building/experimenting yourself.

quotes.topic_title: Why CEOs must become ICs again
quotes.text: AI is something you have to play with, and ideally you're playing with both the packaged up app or solution that you've built with it, but you're also playing around directly with the underlying primitives who are using the models either via API or via a chat interface. You're really pushing them to the boundaries.
quotes.speaker: Howie Liu
quotes.context: A concrete methodology for leaders/practitioners: use the product and the raw model primitives, stress-testing limits to understand the true solution space.

quotes.topic_title: Using AI aggressively for strategic insight
quotes.text: I take pride in being the number one most expensive in inference cost user of Airtable AI, not just within our own company, but I think for a long time I was globally across all our customers vault.
quotes.speaker: Howie Liu
quotes.context: A counterintuitive benchmark: treating AI usage (and even cost) as a leadership KPI for extracting strategic leverage.

quotes.topic_title: Using AI aggressively for strategic insight
quotes.text: I'm extremely intentionally wasteful. Wasteful in the sense of I'll do something that costs maybe hundreds of dollars of actual inference costs. For instance, doing a lot of LLM calls against long transcripts of let's say, sales calls to extract different types of insights like here's the product apps, identify or here's summaries, et cetera.
quotes.speaker: Howie Liu
quotes.context: A practical example of spending real inference dollars to mine sales-call transcripts for product/market insights.

quotes.topic_title: Using AI aggressively for strategic insight
quotes.text: And we also have now a capability that's basically like an LLM map reduce. So effectively, even if you can't fit the entire corpus of content into one LLM call, because the context window limitations, we'll map through all of this content and break it up into chunks and then perform an LLM call on each one and then perform an aggregation LLM call on those chunks.
quotes.speaker: Howie Liu
quotes.context: A reusable methodology (map-reduce for LLMs) for analyzing corpuses that exceed context windows.

quotes.topic_title: Using AI aggressively for strategic insight
quotes.text: But for me, hundreds of dollars spent on this exercise is trivial compared to the potential strategic value of having better insights.
quotes.speaker: Howie Liu
quotes.context: A clear ROI heuristic: compare inference costs to the strategic value of improved decision-making, not to “cheapness.”

quotes.topic_title: Using AI aggressively for strategic insight
quotes.text: You could pay a consulting firm literally millions of dollars to get that quality of work.
quotes.speaker: Howie Liu
quotes.context: A concrete cost comparison that reframes AI spend as a substitute for far more expensive human/consulting analysis.

quotes.topic_title: Changing CEO calendar to enable building
quotes.text: Yeah, so I actually cut my one-on-one roster by default, and the idea is not that I don't want to spend time one-on-one with people, but rather that I found that the ... Just having more standing one-on-ones actually precludes me from engaging in more timely topics.
quotes.speaker: Howie Liu
quotes.context: A counterintuitive calendar change: fewer recurring 1:1s creates space for higher-leverage, time-sensitive work.

quotes.topic_title: Changing CEO calendar to enable building
quotes.text: I like to think of the best types of meetings as very urgency driven.
quotes.speaker: Howie Liu
quotes.context: A simple heuristic for meeting design: prioritize urgency and timeliness over routine cadence.

quotes.topic_title: Changing CEO calendar to enable building
quotes.text: It's almost a barbell approach where it's like if you're going to spend time with somebody in a freeform way, actually do it in a high quality, not forced weekly ritual way.
quotes.speaker: Howie Liu
quotes.context: A memorable relationship-management model: pair deep, high-quality time with focused execution touchpoints instead of weekly 1:1 rituals.

quotes.topic_title: Changing CEO calendar to enable building
quotes.text: Now, we have a weekly basically sprint check-in on all of our AI execution stuff, which now is half the company or half the EPD org is working on AI capabilities.
quotes.speaker: Howie Liu
quotes.context: A concrete operating cadence plus a specific scope/data point showing how broadly AI work has been staffed.

quotes.topic_title: Changing CEO calendar to enable building
quotes.text: We're trying to ship very quickly, like I basically want to always ask the question, how would an AI native company, like a cursor or windsurf, et cetera, how would they execute? And are we executing as fast as them and taking advantage of all the new stuff as well as them?
quotes.speaker: Howie Liu
quotes.context: A benchmarking question leaders can adopt to set execution speed standards against best-in-class AI-native peers.

quotes.topic_title: Reorg to fast-thinking and slow-thinking teams
quotes.text: But it has the disadvantage of yeah, you tend to think incrementally when everyone's remit is actually a feature that they incrementally improve by definition as opposed to thinking about a mission or a outcome goal that might need to coordinate dramatic changes across a wider set of surface areas instead of just each one incrementally improving.
quotes.speaker: Howie Liu
quotes.context: A clear diagnosis of why feature-based team ownership can unintentionally bias organizations toward incrementalism over outcome-driven, cross-surface change.

quotes.topic_title: Reorg to fast-thinking and slow-thinking teams
quotes.text: So we did this recent reorg where now we have what I call the fast thinking group, which officially is called AI platform, but it really means we want to just ship a bunch of new capabilities on a near weekly basis.
quotes.speaker: Howie Liu
quotes.context: Introduces a practical org design framework—explicitly separating a team optimized for weekly shipping velocity.

quotes.topic_title: Reorg to fast-thinking and slow-thinking teams
quotes.text: And then separately, we have the slow thinking group, and that's not meant to be better or worse. It's literally like you need fast and slow thinking in the common sense to operate as a human.
quotes.speaker: Howie Liu
quotes.context: Defines the mental model behind the split: different execution modes are both necessary and should be structurally supported.

quotes.topic_title: Reorg to fast-thinking and slow-thinking teams
quotes.text: We can't just ship a new piece of infrastructure that has a lot of data complexity like our data store HyperDB that now can handle multi-hundred million record data sets. That's not something you ship in a week in a hacky prototype.
quotes.speaker: Howie Liu
quotes.context: A concrete example and constraint that justifies why “slow thinking” teams exist—deep infrastructure work has different cadence requirements.

quotes.topic_title: Reorg to fast-thinking and slow-thinking teams
quotes.text: Because the fast execution, the AI stuff, that creates the top of funnel excitement that also inspires new use cases and new users to come to Airtable, including in large enterprise, right? Enterprises can use this stuff too. It's not just like a SMB thing, but the slow thinking basically allows those initial seeds of adoption to Sprout and grow into much larger deployments.
quotes.speaker: Howie Liu
quotes.context: Explains how the two-speed org design works as a system: fast teams drive demand, slow teams convert it into durable enterprise-scale adoption.

quotes.topic_title: Who thrives in the fast-thinking AI group
quotes.text: But I think the fast thinking part, it really just requires a lot of ... Somebody who's able to operate with a lot of autonomy, who's entrepreneurial in nature.
quotes.speaker: Howie Liu
quotes.context: Defines the core archetype Airtable looks for in a fast-execution AI team: high-autonomy, entrepreneurial operators.

quotes.topic_title: Who thrives in the fast-thinking AI group
quotes.text: But also there are some really, really capable people who we didn't literally have to acquire in, and yet, they're just able to think full stack about the problem and the user experience.
quotes.speaker: Howie Liu
quotes.context: Counters the idea that you need ex-founders via acquisition to move fast—what matters is full-stack product thinking.

quotes.topic_title: Who thrives in the fast-thinking AI group
quotes.text: And that's a capability that there's so much ambiguity in some of the design decisions around it. And you have to blend that design thinking with some of the technical constraints of what can the AI models actually one shot effectively?
quotes.speaker: Howie Liu
quotes.context: A practical product-development lens for AI: design decisions must be grounded in model constraints like one-shot reliability.

quotes.topic_title: Who thrives in the fast-thinking AI group
quotes.text: And if not, how do you add in the right human workflow for approval and review, and the reprompting and so on?
quotes.speaker: Howie Liu
quotes.context: Actionable guidance for shipping AI features: explicitly design human-in-the-loop workflows when the model can’t reliably do it alone.

quotes.topic_title: Who thrives in the fast-thinking AI group
quotes.text: But I think to me what's under executed today in the world of AI products is there's so many awesome capabilities of AI, and most of them are really under merchandise, and there's very poor, actually, visual or otherwise metaphors or affordances given to users to help represent or understand what those underlying capabilities are.
quotes.speaker: Howie Liu
quotes.context: A contrarian UX critique: the biggest gap in AI products is not model capability but how poorly products communicate and surface it to users.

quotes.topic_title: Speed and shipping as AI product advantage
quotes.text: One is he has this concept of whenever something is being worked on, he's always asking, " Is this maximally accelerated? How do we move faster? If this is important, what would allow us to move faster?"
quotes.speaker: Lenny Rachitsky
quotes.context: A repeatable execution framework for continuously pressure-testing whether work is moving as fast as it should.

quotes.topic_title: Speed and shipping as AI product advantage
quotes.text: with AI, you often don't know what it can do and what people want to do with it until it's out. So there's this need to get it out, and that'll tell you what it should be.
quotes.speaker: Lenny Rachitsky
quotes.context: A product-development methodology for AI: ship early to discover real use cases and user demand through live usage.

quotes.topic_title: Speed and shipping as AI product advantage
quotes.text: the best way to get AI value out there is experientially, right.
quotes.speaker: Howie Liu
quotes.context: A guiding principle that emphasizes hands-on product experience over explanations, decks, or abstract positioning.

quotes.topic_title: Speed and shipping as AI product advantage
quotes.text: I think to me, it's a real proof point that ChatGPT is arguably the most successful kind of PLG product of all time, just in terms of sheer scale of users. Like they announced 700 million... Is it MAUs or week... I think it's actually-
quotes.speaker: Howie Liu
quotes.context: A concrete example/data point used to argue that frictionless self-serve access can drive unprecedented AI adoption.

quotes.topic_title: Speed and shipping as AI product advantage
quotes.text: We now made our agent the default way of doing everything in Airtable, and it's now the Airtable app, as you know, it is almost like an artifact that's manipulated by and can be tool used by the agent.
quotes.speaker: Howie Liu
quotes.context: A bold product-architecture shift: make the agent the primary interface and treat the app as something the agent operates on.

quotes.topic_title: Why Airtable’s homepage became AI app-building
quotes.text: as capabilities of these underlying models evolve, the form factor in the product UX also needs to evolve with it.
quotes.speaker: Howie Liu
quotes.context: A product strategy framework: UX should track model capability shifts (e.g., autocomplete → agentic builders) rather than staying fixed.

quotes.topic_title: Why Airtable’s homepage became AI app-building
quotes.text: You can't fool yourself and just say like, "Okay, I'm going to throw in some AI stuff on the landing... on the marketing site, put in a couple AI features, and call it a day."
quotes.speaker: Howie Liu
quotes.context: A blunt warning to avoid superficial AI retrofits and instead rethink the product and company posture end-to-end.

quotes.topic_title: Why Airtable’s homepage became AI app-building
quotes.text: I think you actually have to take a clean slate approach to saying, "How would our mission best be expressed? If you were literally founding a new company from scratch with the same mission, how would you execute on that mission using a fully AI native approach?"
quotes.speaker: Howie Liu
quotes.context: A repeatable methodology for incumbents: re-derive the product as if founding today, then decide what legacy assets help or hurt.

quotes.topic_title: Why Airtable’s homepage became AI app-building
quotes.text: And if you can't really introspect and say, "Look, I think I'm better off doing this with the pieces that I have for my existing business and product," then I think you should sell. You should find a buyer for that company and then go.
quotes.speaker: Howie Liu
quotes.context: A hard decision rule: if legacy assets don’t improve your AI-native execution, exit and restart rather than dragging the old company forward.

quotes.topic_title: Why Airtable’s homepage became AI app-building
quotes.text: Meaning the problem with vibe coding, especially if we're building business apps... So I should clarify that we want to democratize software creation, but specifically, we are focused on business apps.
quotes.speaker: Howie Liu
quotes.context: A positioning insight: the right AI app-building approach depends on the domain, and business apps have different reliability/security needs than viral consumer apps.

quotes.topic_title: Practical playbook for founders in AI transition
quotes.text: So one that you just touched on is just if you were to start today, what will you do?
quotes.speaker: Lenny Rachitsky
quotes.context: A simple but powerful reframing prompt for founders to redesign strategy as if the company were founded in the AI era.

quotes.topic_title: Practical playbook for founders in AI transition
quotes.text: What would that business be? Plus, how can... do we have an unfair advantage with the thing we've done in the past?
quotes.speaker: Lenny Rachitsky
quotes.context: Pairs a clean-slate reset with a legacy-asset advantage check to guide what to keep vs. reinvent.

quotes.topic_title: Practical playbook for founders in AI transition
quotes.text: And then the other... circling back to stuff you've shared already, there's just creating a sense of urgency and pace and getting people to understand this is how things move in AI, and we need to create this fast-thinking team.
quotes.speaker: Lenny Rachitsky
quotes.context: Highlights organizational speed/urgency as a structural requirement for competing in AI-driven markets.

quotes.topic_title: Practical playbook for founders in AI transition
quotes.text: One, I try to use as many different AI products, including not Airtable, as I can, and both literally for the novelty factor and just some new cool demo comes out.
quotes.speaker: Howie Liu
quotes.context: Encourages leaders to build firsthand intuition by actively using a wide range of AI tools, not just their own product.

quotes.topic_title: Practical playbook for founders in AI transition
quotes.text: Like Runway release their immersive world engine, and so I'm going to go try it out.
quotes.speaker: Howie Liu
quotes.context: A concrete example of staying current by immediately testing new AI capabilities as they launch.

quotes.topic_title: Howie’s daily practice: try everything, build side projects
quotes.text: I try to invent little, almost like side projects of my own, to have a real reason to use these products.
quotes.speaker: Howie Liu
quotes.context: A practical methodology: create small self-imposed projects to force real usage and learning, not just passive exposure.

quotes.topic_title: Howie’s daily practice: try everything, build side projects
quotes.text: I think coming up with these different fun weekend projects is a really useful construct to force myself to actually try these products in a more than just a Twitch click way.
quotes.speaker: Howie Liu
quotes.context: A repeatable practice for practitioners: move from superficial demos to hands-on workflow testing via “weekend projects.”

quotes.topic_title: Howie’s daily practice: try everything, build side projects
quotes.text: there's a difference between just understanding the model but then also understanding the product form factors in which they can be placed, right.
quotes.speaker: Howie Liu
quotes.context: A key mental model: model capability knowledge is insufficient without understanding how it translates into usable product experiences.

quotes.topic_title: Howie’s daily practice: try everything, build side projects
quotes.text: This is the equivalent of that, but there's major new releases and products and so on every week, not every year.
quotes.speaker: Howie Liu
quotes.context: A cadence shift data point: AI competition and learning loops now operate weekly, implying faster iteration and monitoring cycles.

quotes.topic_title: Howie’s daily practice: try everything, build side projects
quotes.text: You can't just read the write-up on TechCrunch or even a tweet about a new capability. You kind of have to try it to really get a sense of what it is.
quotes.speaker: Howie Liu
quotes.context: Counter to “stay informed” via reading: experiential testing is required to understand AI capabilities and product implications.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: I use Claude at least 10 times a day.
quotes.speaker: Lenny Rachitsky
quotes.context: A concrete usage frequency that sets a high bar for integrating AI into daily workflows.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: Just last week, I was preparing for an interview with a very fancy guest, and I had Claude tell me what are all the questions that other podcast hosts have asked this guest so that I don't ask them these questions.
quotes.speaker: Lenny Rachitsky
quotes.context: A specific, replicable tactic for using AI to de-duplicate research and improve interview/question quality.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: You can throw a hundred-page strategy document at it and ask it for insights, or you can dump all your user research and ask it to find patterns.
quotes.speaker: Lenny Rachitsky
quotes.context: A practical workflow pattern: use AI for synthesis across large, messy inputs to extract insights and themes.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: One is really, really, really stressing this idea of go play with this stuff.
quotes.speaker: Howie Liu
quotes.context: A leadership directive that emphasizes experimentation as the fastest path to building AI fluency across teams.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: there's a difference when you go in and you're kind of just trying to check the box and get a job done. There's a difference when you come in with a curiosity and you're kind of exploring, right.
quotes.speaker: Howie Liu
quotes.context: A memorable mental model contrasting compliance-driven usage vs curiosity-driven exploration to accelerate learning.

quotes.topic_title: Raising the bar: expectations for PMs and teams
quotes.text: One is really, really, really stressing this idea of go play with this stuff.
quotes.speaker: Howie Liu
quotes.context: Sets a clear behavioral expectation for teams adopting AI: hands-on experimentation as a first-class priority.

quotes.topic_title: Raising the bar: expectations for PMs and teams
quotes.text: And I mean, when I say play, I really mean play in the psychological sense of there's a difference when you go in and you're kind of just trying to check the box and get a job done. There's a difference when you come in with a curiosity and you're kind of exploring, right.
quotes.speaker: Howie Liu
quotes.context: Introduces a practical mental model—“checkbox mode” vs “curiosity/exploration mode”—to drive deeper learning with AI tools.

quotes.topic_title: Raising the bar: expectations for PMs and teams
quotes.text: And I kind of try to lead by example, by literally going and sharing out links or screenshots of the things that I'm doing in these various products.
quotes.speaker: Howie Liu
quotes.context: A concrete leadership tactic: share artifacts of AI work (links/screenshots) to normalize usage and accelerate org learning.

quotes.topic_title: Raising the bar: expectations for PMs and teams
quotes.text: So, as an example, I will go into one of the prototyping tools and show, "Hey, I built a marketing landing page for this new capability we're launching." I created a landing page for it in Replit, let's say, and now I'm sharing that link.
quotes.speaker: Howie Liu
quotes.context: Provides a specific, replicable example of using AI-enabled prototyping to move faster than traditional documentation workflows.

quotes.topic_title: Raising the bar: expectations for PMs and teams
quotes.text: Or instead of me writing a perfect memo on a topic, I'll actually just prompt my way into getting a chat thread or a chat output that basically covers all the content that I care about and maybe even ask it to, "Okay, summarize this all into a final memo output," and then intentionally share that rather than expose the fact that I'm using AI in this way and here's literally how I'm prompting it so you can follow along as well.
quotes.speaker: Howie Liu
quotes.context: A counterintuitive practice: share the AI-generated thread and prompts (not just the polished memo) to teach others how to work.
